content.content: ### How to Prevent Home Medication Mistakes #### Ask Questions! __No question is too trivial to ask. Trust your instincts.__ Embedded content: https://youtu.be/MEFJfpKslQg 1\. Write down all your questions to ask your doctor or nurse or ask someone to do it for you.[^7] 2\. Bring a family member or advocate to help listen and speak up for you.[^7] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/od6ksU6IIAE 3\. Write in your phone, mobile device, computer or notebook the answers given by the doctor.[^10] #### Make and Keep a Medication List: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/fICtiLrX8dk [Create a Medication List from ISMP](https://www.pihhealth.org/app/files/public/6622387d-5fa4-4a61-a14d-d72f25e1f224/Personal-Medicine-List.pdf "Create a Medication List from ISMP") - Make a list of all prescribed & over-the-counter medications, herbal, diet, & vitamin supplements that you take. Add any allergies to this list.[^7] - Bring this list when you visit your doctor.[^7] - Use a medication list mobile app. [Medication Guide mobile app from Drugs.com](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/drugs-com-medication-guide/id599471042 "Medication Guide mobile app from Drugs.com") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/BJI1ToB-Dv8 #### New Medications [^270]: - Ask for a drug information sheet with every new medication. - Why do I need this medication? - What is the medication for? - What will it do? - When do I take the first dose? - How often should this medication be taken? - How much should be taken? - What does "as needed" mean? - How do you get refills? - When will I stop taking this medication? - What are the side effects &/or possible drug interactions? - Where do I get the medication? - Will my insurance pay for this medication? - Are there any foods or drinks that should be avoided? - Can I drive after taking this medication? - __Tell your doctor if you stop taking this or any medication.__ - Can you explain that to me again? __Call your Doctor if you have any of these symptoms from a medication [^96]:__ - Falling asleep mid-sentence - Confusion or dizziness - Itching, rash or hives - Severe pain - Headache - Stomach ache - Loss of muscle control - Increased or decreased heart rate - Nausea, constipation or diarrhea - Low or high blood pressure __Call 911 with these symptoms:__ - Difficulty breathing - Breathing too slowly - Difficulty speaking - Seizure - Partial or total paralysis - Swelling of lips, tongue or face - Vision loss - Loss of muscle control #### Storing Your Medicines [^270][^271]: - Store your medications out of reach of children and pets.  - Always put away every medication every time it’s used. - Make sure the safety cap is locked. - Use a child-proof container when children are in the home. - Teach children about medication safety. - Teach your guests about medication safety. - __Program the Poison Help number 1-800-222-1222 into your phone.__  - Never tell a child that a medication is candy. [Child Medication Safety Tips from PROTECT](https://www.upandaway.org "Child Medication Safety from PROTECT") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/zmVMJZL5who #### Organize Your Medications in a Pill Box: [Storing Your Medicines from MedlinePlus](https://medlineplus.gov/ency/patientinstructions/000534.htm#:~:text=Store%20your%20medicines%20in%20a,medicine%20in%20a%20bathroom%20cabinet. "Storing Your Medicines from MedlinePlus") [Put Your Medicines Up and Away and Out of Sight from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/patientsafety/features/medication-storage.html "Put Your Medicines Up and Away and Out of Sight from the CDC") #### How to Dispose of Medications [^272]: - The best way to dispose of medications is with a [Take Back Day program](https://takebackday.dea.gov/ "Take Back Day from the DEA"), local pharmacy, or [public drug disposal location](https://safe.pharmacy/drug-disposal/ "public drug disposal location from NABP") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/agwaF2kYiUA Embedded content: https://youtu.be/KwIIOsYmF04 [It’s Important to Safely Remove Opioids From Your Home by FDA](https://www.fda.gov/media/123330/download "It’s Important to Safely Remove Opioids From Your Home by FDA") - If a drug disposal place isn’t available, look at the medication label to see if it is on the [FDA Flush List](https://www.fda.gov/drugs/disposal-unused-medicines-what-you-should-know/drug-disposal-fdas-flush-list-certain-medicines#FlushList "FDA Flush List"). - If the medication isn’t on the FDA Flush List, mix inside a plastic bag with  dirt, used coffee grounds, or cat litter. Seal the bag and throw it out  in your trash. Delete all personal information on the bottle or packaging and recyle or trash the empty bottle or package. - Inhaler labels should have disposal instructions. Call your local pharmacy or recycling facility for help. __Inhalers can explode or leak medication if punctured or thrown in a fire.__  #### Medication Safety: [Medication Safety Program from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/medicationsafety/ "Medication Safety from the CDC") [Medication Safety Basics from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/medicationsafety/basics.html "Medication Safety Basics from the CDC") [Tips for Using Medications Safely from NABP](https://safe.pharmacy/safe-use/ "Tips for Using Medications Safely from NABP") [Know Your Over-the-Counter Medications from CHPA](https://www.knowyourotcs.org "Know Your Over-the-Counter Medications from CHPA") [Prevention & Early Action-Partnership to End Addiction](https://drugfree.org/prevention-and-taking-action-early/ "Prevention & Early Action-Partnership to End Addiction")  #### Pediatric Medication Safety: Embedded content: https://youtu.be/lmEKKDtIycM [Medication Safety Advice for New Parents from the FDA](https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/medication-safety-advice-new-parents "Medication Safety Advice for New Parents from the FDA") [^7]: Hallisey J. The Empowered Patient® hospital guide for patients and families. Empowered Patient website. http://engagedpatients.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/empowered_patient_hospital_guide.pdf. Published 2009. Updated 2012. Accessed May 10, 2015. [^10]: Curtiss K. Campaign. ZERO-Patient Safety Checklist. http://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Resources_Checklist_Patient_Safety_Checklist_Collection.pdf. Accessed November 5, 2015.
